Award.AwardTitle: Convergence HTF: From Making to Micro-Manufacture: Reimagining Work Beyond Mass Production

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intelligent, interactive, and highly networked machines --with which people increasingly share their autonomy and agency--are a growing part of the landscape, particularly in regard to work. As automation today moves from the factory floor to knowledge and service occupations, insight and action are needed to reap the benefits in increased productivity and increased job opportunities, and to mitigate social costs. The workshop supported by this award will promote the convergence of multiple fields of inquiry from Computer Science, Human-Computer Interaction, Electrical and Mechanical Engineering, Design, Economics, the Social Sciences, Industrial Engineering and Education to define key challenges and research imperatives of the nexus of humans, technology, and work. Convergence is the deep integration of knowledge, theories, methods, and data from multiple fields to form new and expanded frameworks for addressing scientific and societal challenges and opportunities. This convergence workshop addresses the future of work at the human-technology frontier.

The specific focus of this workshop is to foster a discussion about the re-conceptualization of wealth creation in economically distressed areas by enabling the production of high quality manufactured goods at scales of hundreds and thousands in many distributed locations, but in an effective and sustainable manner. This approach, called "Micro-Manufacture," is grounded in technological advances that facilitate customized production of artifacts (e.g., 3D printing, the Internet; mobile devices, etc.). The workshop aims at initiating a discussion about the feasibility of the micro-manufacturing model. The workshop will also explore the interplay between Maker-based innovation and the engineering processes of Micro-Manufacture. To initiate the Micro-Manufacturing discussion, the perspectives of multiple science, technology, educational and societal interests need to be included. In particular, it is expected that research questions emanating from the workshop will require the deep integration of more than one discipline, from supply chain modeling and product design, to economics, sociology and education, to name only a few. The expected outcomes of the workshop will include the formation of a community of researchers with ideas that cross-cut fields to address Micro-Manufacture; an understanding of how the multiple related research areas interact and the research that is needed to enable Micro-Manufacture; and a publication in the form of a collected volume to inform the research community and broader society of the need, possibility, and challenges relating to Micro-Manufacture. The broader impacts accrue mainly from its potential to address society's pressing need for new configurations of work that may bring employment to a broader range of workers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Discussants across the fields of industrial engineering, computer science, social/occupational psychology, law (IP and trade), business, education, and economics explored the potentials and challenges of Micro-manufacture (making things in quantities of hundreds and thousands), and especially how it may impact the future of work and economies. Participants were drawn from academia, business, and government. The workshop was convened in Washington DC in July 2018. The goals were to explore the implications of Micro-manufacture to the constituent disciplines; to build new interdisciplinary teams; and to explore collaborative research opportunities in Micro-Manufacture. 


The ideas and teams developed through the workshop translated into 2 successful and 2 declined NSF proposals. One successful grant (“Collaborative Research: Preparing Students for the New Manufacturing Economy: An Integrative Learning Approach” NSF ITEST Program #1949439) explores the preparation of high school students for the flexible work teams in a 2-year Career and Technical Education (CTE) program featuring horizontal learning needed for Micro-Manufacture, integrating 'operational knowledge' (digital fabrication, microprocessor electronics, and programming), and 'tactical processes' (production/manufacturing). The current education system is predominantly vertical, emphasizing expertise development within knowledge silos that mirror the vertical organization of mass production-centric work. The project focuses on horizontally-integrated learning to equip students for the broad waterfront of skills and the capacity to grow those skills that are critical to the envisioned small work teams that constitute Micro-Manufacture work groups. The CTE project will feature actual micro-production, with the CTE students making Maker-based learning kits for elementary schools in their school district, and designing, prototyping, and manufacturing for small businesses within their community. 


Another successful proposal is “Broadening Participation for Remote Communities: Situated Distance Telepresence Mentoring through Embodied Communications”: Cyberlearning Program #1917950. This project is predicated on the proposition that micro-fabrication and factories can be instantiated anywhere, including in rural communities. It  investigates the use of telepresence robots and augmented reality distance CTE education to prepare students in rural schools to participate in Micro-Manufacture.


Two other unsuccessful large collaborative proposals explore the convergence aspects of Micro-Manufacture, and artificial intelligence agents to enable live-long broad-waterfront learning needed for Micro-Manufacture. The teams developed through the workshop expects to maintain their collaboration in ongoing efforts. The grants are: 1. “GCR: Micro-Manufacture: Reimagining How We Make Things in the Digital Economy”: Growing Convergence Research Program #2021097. This proposal assembled a large subset of the disciplines represented in the workshop to explore the Micro-Manufacture concept per se. The goal was to build a convergent team to analyze the promise of Micro-Manufacture from multiple perspectives (law, economics, business, technology, education) by curating a body of innovations through university innovation incubators to understand the gaps and solutions needed. The team expects to reformulate the proposal for a Future of Work initiative in 2021. 2. “AI Institute: Institute for Flexible Horizontal Learning: From In-School to Lifelong Support”: AI Research Institute Program #2019898. This proposal built on the workshop’s findings that there is needed for new support for horizontal learners to enable them to participate in the kind of broad-waterfront work needed for Micro-Manufacture. Current educational structures focus on vertical learning structures. While vertical structures are needed to advance specific learning, there is a lack of horizontal learning support that enables the learner to find learning sources across fields. The AI institute was to study horizontal learning support agents that support individuals to pursue knowledge across fields. The proposing team anticipates submitting smaller proposals that explore different aspects of the AI center proposal.
